problems.title: Global Rehabilitation Workforce Shortage Creates Critical Access Gaps
problems.description: The rehabilitation sector faces a severe global workforce shortage, with the World Health Organization estimating a deficit of over 10 million rehabilitation professionals worldwide. This shortage is particularly acute in low- and middle-income countries, where only 2% of the need for rehabilitation services is currently met. In high-income countries, the shortage manifests as extended wait times, reduced service availability in rural areas, and increased burnout among existing practitioners. The aging global population, rising prevalence of chronic conditions, and growing survival rates from previously fatal injuries and illnesses are driving unprecedented demand for rehabilitation services that the current workforce cannot meet. Physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, and rehabilitation physicians are all in critically short supply, creating a cascade of negative health outcomes for patients who cannot access timely care.
problems.summary: A global shortage of over 10 million rehabilitation professionals severely limits access to care, particularly in low-income countries and rural areas, leading to delayed recovery and poorer health outcomes.

problems.title: Speech-Language Pathologist Shortage Delays Critical Early Intervention
problems.description: The United States faces a severe shortage of speech-language pathologists (SLPs), with 28 states reporting shortages in schools and 48% of school districts unable to fill SLP positions. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects 13,700 annual job openings through 2035, but university programs only graduate 9,400 master's-level SLPs per year, creating a widening gap. This shortage is particularly acute in rural and economically disadvantaged areas, leading to wait times of 6-18 months for assessment and treatment. For children with speech and language disorders, these delays occur during critical developmental windows when intervention is most effective. Heavy caseloads exceeding 50-80 students per SLP, extensive paperwork requirements, and stagnating wages contribute to burnout rates exceeding 9% annually, further depleting the workforce. The consequences include missed early intervention opportunities, developmental delays that persist into adulthood, and educational disparities for children in underserved communities.
problems.summary: A severe shortage of speech-language pathologists, with 48% of school districts unable to fill positions, delays critical early intervention for children with communication disorders during vital developmental periods.

problems.title: Cardiac Rehabilitation Critically Underutilized Despite Proven Benefits
problems.description: Cardiac rehabilitation is one of the most effective interventions for patients following heart attacks, heart surgery, or heart failure diagnosis, reducing mortality by 20-30% and hospital readmissions by 25%. Despite this evidence, participation rates remain critically low at only 20-30% of eligible patients, with dropout rates as high as 56%. Barriers include limited program availability (particularly in rural areas), lack of physician referrals, insurance coverage gaps, transportation challenges, work schedule conflicts, and patient perceptions that rehabilitation is unnecessary. Women, minorities, elderly patients, and those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds are disproportionately underrepresented. The COVID-19 pandemic further reduced participation as programs closed or shifted to untested virtual formats. This underutilization represents a massive missed opportunity to prevent recurrent cardiac events, reduce healthcare costs, and improve quality of life for millions of cardiac patients annually.
problems.summary: Despite reducing mortality by 20-30%, cardiac rehabilitation is utilized by only 20-30% of eligible patients due to access barriers, lack of referrals, and patient perceptions, with dropout rates reaching 56%.

problems.title: Pediatric Rehabilitation Access Inequity in Rural and Indigenous Communities
problems.description: Approximately one in six children has a disability requiring rehabilitation services, yet access varies dramatically based on geography and demographics. Children in rural areas, Indigenous communities, and low-income neighborhoods face wait times of 12-24 months for services, must travel hours for appointments, and often cannot access specialized pediatric therapists at all. In northern Indigenous communities, accessing pediatric rehabilitation is a critical priority that remains largely unmet. Families face compounding barriers including adverse weather, inadequate transportation, financial costs of travel, need for childcare for siblings, and cultural/language barriers in service delivery. These disparities result in delayed intervention during critical developmental windows, poorer long-term outcomes, and perpetuation of health inequities across generations.
problems.summary: Children in rural and Indigenous communities face 12-24 month waits for rehabilitation services, with many unable to access specialized care at all due to geographic, financial, and cultural barriers.

problems.title: Rehabilitation Research Evidence Gap Limits Clinical Practice Advancement
problems.description: Physical medicine and rehabilitation (PM&R) is considered the most understudied area of clinical care by NIH consensus panels. Despite rehabilitation services being essential for recovery from injury, illness, and disability, there are very few federally funded rehabilitation research projects compared to other medical specialties, and few evidence-based practice guidelines exist. Methodological challenges unique to rehabilitation research compound the problem: patients are heterogeneous, interventions are complex and multifaceted, appropriate control groups are difficult to design, and meaningful outcome measures are hard to standardize. The gap between research-based knowledge and daily practice can take a decade to close, and changes are difficult to maintain.
problems.summary: Rehabilitation is the most understudied clinical area with few federally funded projects or evidence-based guidelines, leaving clinicians without research-backed recommendations for optimal patient care.

problems.title: Telerehabilitation Clinical Limitations Impede Remote Care Quality
problems.description: While telerehabilitation expanded dramatically during the COVID-19 pandemic and offers promise for extending access to underserved populations, significant clinical limitations impede its effectiveness for many rehabilitation needs. Physical examination capabilities are fundamentally compromised in virtual settingsâ€”therapists cannot perform manual muscle testing, assess joint mobility, evaluate balance and gait patterns accurately, or provide hands-on manual therapy. Assessment of subtle neurological findings, wound healing, and functional mobility is severely limited. For pediatric patients, maintaining attention and engagement through a screen is challenging. Technical barriers including unreliable internet, inadequate devices, and low digital literacy further limit effectiveness. Licensing restrictions prevent therapists from treating patients across state lines.
problems.summary: Telerehabilitation cannot replicate hands-on assessment and treatment essential for many rehabilitation needs, creating quality gaps despite expanded access during and after the pandemic.

problems.title: Stroke Rehabilitation Faces Persistent Cognitive Impairment Challenges
problems.description: Between 30-70% of stroke survivors experience lasting cognitive impairments affecting memory, attention, executive function, and processing speed, yet cognitive rehabilitation remains underdeveloped compared to physical rehabilitation. Many stroke survivors who regain physical function continue to struggle with returning to work, managing daily activities, and maintaining relationships due to cognitive deficits that go undertreated. Current cognitive rehabilitation approaches show limited evidence of effectiveness, and there is no consensus on optimal treatment protocols. Cognitive impairment frequently co-occurs with depression and fatigue, creating a complex syndrome that is difficult to address.

problems.title: Rehabilitation Outcomes Measurement Lacks Standardization Across Settings
problems.description: The rehabilitation field lacks standardized outcome measures used consistently across clinical settings, research studies, and payment systems. This fragmentation severely limits the ability to compare treatment effectiveness, benchmark quality, conduct meaningful research, and demonstrate value to payers. Different facilities use different assessment tools, making it impossible to track patient outcomes across the continuum of care or aggregate data for quality improvement. Even within a single diagnosis like stroke, dozens of different outcome measures are used with varying psychometric properties and minimal correlation between them.
problems.summary: Lack of standardized outcome measures across rehabilitation settings prevents meaningful comparison of treatments, benchmarking of quality, and advancement of evidence-based practice.

problems.title: Physical Therapy Access Barriers Limit Non-Opioid Pain Management Options
problems.description: Physical therapy is recommended as a first-line treatment for many chronic pain conditions and as an alternative to opioid medications, yet significant access barriers prevent many patients from receiving this care. Insurance coverage limitations including high copays, visit caps, and prior authorization requirements create financial barriers. Geographic maldistribution of physical therapists leaves rural areas underserved. Wait times for appointments can extend weeks to months. Direct access laws vary by state, with many still requiring physician referral before physical therapy can begin.
problems.summary: Despite being recommended over opioids for many pain conditions, physical therapy remains inaccessible due to insurance barriers, provider shortages, and referral requirements.

problems.title: Rehabilitation Technology Adoption Hindered by Cost and Implementation Barriers
problems.description: Emerging rehabilitation technologies including robotic-assisted therapy devices, virtual reality systems, wearable sensors, AI-powered assessment tools, and brain-computer interfaces show promise for improving outcomes, but adoption remains limited due to substantial barriers. Equipment costs range from tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands of dollars, with uncertain return on investment and inadequate reimbursement. Implementation requires significant training, workflow redesign, and ongoing technical support that many facilities cannot provide.
